Because you know we in environmental engineering we have this concept of uh redundancy or functional redundancy when you have many members of the community that can do the same function, it's a more resilient community because if you have 20 doctors and one gets sick, there's another 19 that can see patients, but if you only have one doctor and he gets sick, who's going to see the patients? So it's the same with the microbes, right? So.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Heather Bean

So a bacteria if it's just in monoculture with another bacteria might ramp up virulence factors that would really help it kill or out compete its competitor, but those virulence factors might also be uh immune modulators and signal to the host that it's um that that bacterium needs to be destroyed. meeting_annotations.speaker: Corinne Maurice
meeting_annotations.transcript: You do need the the specific isolates approach, but you can't base everything on that because for sure whatever you find with one isolate, as soon as you take that same isolate that was giving you this signal, you place it with a friend, it just goes haywire. It's it will not be the same thing. Yeah. So I I can give you an example from environmental engineering. Um, I did my PhD working with bacteria that can respire chlorinated solvents and what they do is they take out the chlorines and they make these solvents not toxic anymore and this is used, this is used for bioremediation. There are cultures with these microbes. If you take the single microbe which is the alcoides and have the microbe do the the reaction which destroys this pollutant, the microbe is very slow if it's in pure culture. But if you have it in mixed culture with friends that can provide cofactors, electron donor and a few other fun things, which is how we use it in the environment, much faster.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Corinne Maurice
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's it's totally normal because we tend to hear way more about probiotics. So probiotics are live microorganisms. It's what you're going to find in your yogurt, in your cheese, in your fermented food, okay? So you're taking the live microorganism with the hopes that it will possibly like colonize your gut and give you all the health benefits associated with it. Prebiotics, it's it's um it's a molecule, it's a compound. It's food for these microorganisms. So the idea would be that a prebiotic basically would be like your your your broccoli um that allows your specific um for to grow in the system. So prebiotics is all about giving the right um I guess nutrient sources to the bacteria that you want to either enhance or you deplete these sources so that you can like limit the growth of the bacteria that you don't want.
